watertap3.wt_units.alum_addition module¶

class watertap3.wt_units.alum_addition.UnitProcess(*args, **kwds)¶

Bases: watertap3.wt_units.wt_unit.WT3UnitProcess

elect()¶

Electricity intensity for chemical additions is a function of lift height, pump efficiency, and motor efficiency.

The current release of WaterTAP3 uses default values that cannot be edited by the user:

Assumptions:

  • Lift height [ft] = 100

  • Pump efficiency = 90%

  • Motor efficiency = 90%

Calculations:

  • Electricity Intensity [kWh/m3] = (Alum flow * Lift height) / (Pump efficiency * Motor efficiency * Flow in)

Returns

Electricity intensity [kWh/m3]

fixed_cap(unit_params)¶

“unit_params” are the unit parameters passed to the model from the input sheet as a Python dictionary.

EXAMPLE: {‘dose’: 10}

Fixed capital for alum addition is a function of alum dose, alum solution flow, and the number of units.

Assumptions:

  • Number of units = 2

Parameters

dose (float) – Alum dose [mg/L]

Returns

Alum addition fixed capital cost [$MM]

get_costing(unit_params=None, year=None)¶

Initialize the unit in WaterTAP3.

solution_vol_flow()¶

Determine alum solution flow rate in gal / day

Assumptions:

  • Alum solution density [kg/m3] = 1360

  • Ratio in solution = 50%

Calculations:

  1. Chemical rate [kg/hr] = Flow in * Alum dose

  2. Solution flow [gal/day] = Chemical rate / (Density * Ratio)

Returns

Alum solution flow [gal/day]

elect()¶

Electricity intensity for chemical additions is a function of lift height, pump efficiency, and motor efficiency.

The current release of WaterTAP3 uses default values that cannot be edited by the user:

Assumptions:

  • Lift height [ft] = 100

  • Pump efficiency = 90%

  • Motor efficiency = 90%

Calculations:

  • Electricity Intensity [kWh/m3] = (Ammonia flow * Lift height) / (Pump efficiency * Motor efficiency * Flow in)

Electricity intensity [kWh/m3]

EXAMPLE: {‘dose’: 10}

Fixed capital for ammonia addition is a function of ammonia dose, ammonia solution flow, and the number of units.

solution_vol_flow()¶

Determine ammonia solution flow rate in gal / day

Assumptions:

  • Ammonia solution density [kg/m3] = 900

  • Ratio in solution = 30%

Calculations:

  1. Chemical rate [kg/hr] = Flow in * Ammonia dose

  2. Solution flow [gal/day] = Chemical rate / (Density * Ratio)

Returns

Ammonia solution flow [gal/day]

elect()¶

Electricity intensity for chemical additions is a function of lift height, pump efficiency, and motor efficiency.

The current release of WaterTAP3 uses default values that cannot be edited by the user:

Assumptions:

  • Lift height [ft] = 100

  • Pump efficiency = 90%

  • Motor efficiency = 90%

Calculations:

  • Electricity Intensity [kWh/m3] = (Anti-scalant flow * Lift height) / (Pump efficiency * Motor efficiency * Flow in)

Returns

Electricity intensity [kWh/m3]

fixed_cap(unit_params)¶

“unit_params” are the unit parameters passed to the model from the input sheet as a Python dictionary.

EXAMPLE: {‘dose’: 10}

Fixed capital for anti-scalant addition is a function of anti-scalant dose, anti-scalant solution flow, and the number of units.

Assumptions: * Number of units = 2

Returns

Anti-scalant addition fixed capital cost [$MM]

get_costing(unit_params=None, year=None)¶

solution_vol_flow()¶

Assumptions:

  • Anti-scalant solution density [kg/m3] = 1021

  • Ratio in solution = 50%

Calculations:

  1. Chemical rate [kg/hr] = Flow in * Anti-scalant dose

  2. Solution flow [gal/day] = Chemical rate / Density

elect()¶

Electricity intensity for chemical additions is a function of lift height, pump efficiency, and motor efficiency.

The current release of WaterTAP3 uses default values that cannot be edited by the user:

Assumptions:

  • Lift height [ft] = 100

  • Pump efficiency = 90%

  • Motor efficiency = 90%

Calculations:

  • Electricity Intensity [kWh/m3] = (Chemical flow * Lift height) / (Pump efficiency * Motor efficiency * Flow in)

Returns

Electricity intensity [kWh/m3]

fixed_cap(unit_params)¶

“unit_params” are the unit parameters passed to the model from the input sheet as a Python dictionary.

EXAMPLE: {‘dose’: 10}

Fixed capital for chemical addition is a function of chemical dose, chemical solution flow, and the number of units.

Parameters

  • chemical_name (str) – Chemical name to be used.

  • dose (float) – Dose of chemical [mg/L]

Returns

Chemical addition fixed capital cost [$MM]

get_costing(unit_params=None, year=None)¶

Initialize the unit in WaterTAP3.

solution_vol_flow()¶

Determine chemical solution flow rate in gal / day

Assumptions:

  • Chemical solution density [kg/m3] = 1000

Calculations:

  1. Chemical rate [kg/hr] = Flow in * Chemical dose

  2. Solution flow [gal/day] = Chemical rate / Density

Returns

Chemical solution flow [gal/day]

elect()¶

Electricity intensity for chemical additions is a function of lift height, pump efficiency, and motor efficiency.

The current release of WaterTAP3 uses default values that cannot be edited by the user:

Assumptions:

  • Lift height [ft] = 100

  • Pump efficiency = 90%

  • Motor efficiency = 90%

Calculations:

  • Electricity Intensity [kWh/m3] = (Ferric flow * Lift height) / (Pump efficiency * Motor efficiency * Flow in)

Returns

Electricity intensity [kWh/m3]

fixed_cap(unit_params)¶

“unit_params” are the unit parameters passed to the model from the input sheet as a Python dictionary.

EXAMPLE: {‘dose’: 10}

Fixed capital for ferric chloride addition is a function of ferric dose, ferric solution flow, and the number of units.

Assumptions:

  • Number of units = 2

Returns

Ferric addition fixed capital cost [$MM]

get_costing(unit_params=None, year=None)¶

Initialize the unit in WaterTAP3.

solution_vol_flow()¶

Determine ferric chloride solution flow rate in gal / day

Assumptions:

  • Ferric solution density [kg/m3] = 1460

  • Ratio in solution = 42%

Calculations:

  1. Chemical rate [kg/hr] = Flow in * Ferric dose

  2. Solution flow [gal/day] = Chemical rate / (Density * Ratio)

Returns

Ferric solution flow [gal/day]

watertap3.wt_units.holding_tank module¶

class watertap3.wt_units.holding_tank.UnitProcess(*args, **kwds)¶

Bases: watertap3.wt_units.wt_unit.WT3UnitProcess

elect()¶

WaterTAP3 has no electricity intensity associated with storage tanks.

fixed_cap(unit_params)¶

“unit_params” are the unit parameters passed to the model from the input sheet as a Python dictionary.

EXAMPLE: {‘avg_storage_time’: 24, ‘surge_cap’: 0.2}

Parameters

  • avg_storage_time – storage time in hours

  • surge_cap – is the surge capacity used for calculating storage volume, expressed as a fraction of the total flow (e.g. for 20% surge capacity, use 0.2)

Returns

Fixed capital for storage tanks.

get_costing(unit_params=None, year=None)¶

Initialize the unit in WaterTAP3.

elect()¶

Electricity intensity for chemical additions is a function of lift height, pump efficiency, and motor efficiency.

  • Pump efficiency = 90%

Returns

EXAMPLE: {‘dose’: 10}

Fixed capital for HCl addition is a function of HCl dose, HCl solution flow, and the number of units.

  • Number of units = 2

  2. Solution flow [gal/day] = Chemical rate / Density

watertap3.wt_units.lime_addition module¶

class watertap3.wt_units.lime_addition.UnitProcess(*args, **kwds)¶

Bases: watertap3.wt_units.wt_unit.WT3UnitProcess

elect()¶

Electricity intensity for chemical additions is a function of lift height, pump efficiency, and motor efficiency.

The current release of WaterTAP3 uses default values that cannot be edited by the user:

Assumptions:

  • Lift height [ft] = 100

  • Pump efficiency = 90%

  • Motor efficiency = 90%

Calculations:

  • Electricity Intensity [kWh/m3] = (Lime flow * Lift height) / (Pump efficiency * Motor efficiency * Flow in)

Returns

Electricity intensity [kWh/m3]

fixed_cap(unit_params)¶

“unit_params” are the unit parameters passed to the model from the input sheet as a Python dictionary.

EXAMPLE: {‘lime’: 10}

Fixed capital for lime addition is a function of lime dose, lime solution flow, and the number of units.

Assumptions:

  • Number of units = 2

Parameters

lime (float) – Lime dose [mg/L]

Returns

Lime addition fixed capital cost [$MM]

get_costing(unit_params=None, year=None)¶

Initialize the unit in WaterTAP3.

solution_vol_flow()¶

Determine lime solution flow rate in gal / day

Assumptions:

  • Lime solution density [kg/m3] = 1250

  • Ratio in solution = 50%

Calculations:

  1. Chemical rate [kg/hr] = Flow in * Lime dose

  2. Solution flow [gal/day] = Chemical rate / Density

Returns

Lime solution vol. flow [gal/day], Lime solution mass flow [lb/day]

watertap3.wt_units.lime_softening module¶

class watertap3.wt_units.lime_softening.UnitProcess(*args, **kwds)¶

Bases: watertap3.wt_units.wt_unit.WT3UnitProcess

elect()¶

Electricity intensity for chemical additions is a function of lift height, pump efficiency, and motor efficiency.

The current release of WaterTAP3 uses default values that cannot be edited by the user:

Assumptions:

  • Lift height [ft] = 100

  • Pump efficiency = 90%

  • Motor efficiency = 90%

Calculations:

  • Electricity Intensity [kWh/m3] = (Alum flow * Lift height) / (Pump efficiency * Motor efficiency * Flow in)

Returns

Electricity intensity [kWh/m3]

fixed_cap(unit_params)¶

“unit_params” are the unit parameters passed to the model from the input sheet as a Python dictionary.

EXAMPLE: {‘lime’: 10}

Fixed capital for lime addition is a function of lime dose, lime solution flow, and the number of units.

Assumptions:

  • Number of units = 2

Parameters

lime (float) – Lime dose [mg/L]

Returns

Lime addition fixed capital cost [$MM]

get_costing(unit_params=None, year=None)¶

Initialize the unit in WaterTAP3.

solution_vol_flow()¶

Determine alum solution flow rate in gal / day

Assumptions:

  • Alum solution density [kg/m3] = 1360

  • Ratio in solution = 50%

Calculations:

  1. Chemical rate [kg/hr] = Flow in * Alum dose

  2. Solution flow [gal/day] = Chemical rate / (Density * Ratio)

Returns

Alum solution flow [gal/day]

elect()¶

Electricity intensity for chemical additions is a function of lift height, pump efficiency, and motor efficiency.

The current release of WaterTAP3 uses default values that cannot be edited by the user:

Assumptions:

  • Lift height [ft] = 100

  • Pump efficiency = 90%

  • Motor efficiency = 90%

Calculations:

  • Electricity Intensity [kWh/m3] = (Sodium bisulfite flow * Lift height) / (Pump efficiency * Motor efficiency * Flow in)

Returns

Electricity intensity [kWh/m3]

fixed_cap(unit_params)¶

“unit_params” are the unit parameters passed to the model from the input sheet as a Python dictionary.

EXAMPLE: {‘dose’: 10}

Fixed capital for sodium bisulfite addition is a function of sodium bisulfite dose, sodium bisulfite solution flow, and the number of units.

Assumptions:

  • Number of units = 2

Parameters

dose (float) – Sodium bisulfite dose [mg/L]

Returns

Sodium bisulfite addition fixed capital cost [$MM]

Assumptions:

  • Sodium bisulfite solution density [kg/m3] = 1360

  • Ratio in solution = 50%

Calculations:

  1. Chemical rate [kg/hr] = Flow in * Sodium bisulfite dose

  2. Solution flow [gal/day] = Chemical rate / (Density * Ratio)

Electricity intensity for chemical additions is a function of lift height, pump efficiency, and motor efficiency.

Assumptions:

watertap3.wt_units.uv_aop module¶

class watertap3.wt_units.uv_aop.UnitProcess(*args, **kwds)¶

Bases: watertap3.wt_units.wt_unit.WT3UnitProcess

elect()¶
fixed_cap(unit_params)¶

“unit_params” are the unit parameters passed to the model from the input sheet as a Python dictionary.

EXAMPLE: {‘aop’: True, ‘uv_dose’: 350, ‘dose’: 5, ‘chemical_name’: ‘Hydrogen Peroxide’}

Parameters

  • aop (bool) – (required) Boolean that determines if UV is used with AOP. Must be either True or False

  • uvt_in (float) – (optional, default is 0.9) UV transmission (UVT) into unit

  • uv_dose (float) – (optional, default is 100) Reduction Equivalent Dose (RED) [mJ/cm2]

  • dose (float) – (optional, no default) Dose for oxidant (if AOP) [mg/L]

  • chemical_name (str) – (optional, default is 'Hydrogen_Peroxide') Name of oxidant used for AOP.

Important

chemical_name parameter must match exactly with chemical entry in catalyst_chemicals.csv or there will be an error.

Returns

Fixed capital for UV or UV+AOP unit [$MM]

get_costing(unit_params=None, year=None)¶

Initialize the unit in WaterTAP3.

solution_vol_flow()¶

Determine oxidant solution flow rate in gal / day

Calculations:

  1. Oxidant flow rate [kg/hr] = Flow in * Oxidant dose

Returns

Oxidant solution flow [gal/day]

uv_regress()¶

Determine a, b costing parameters as a function of flow, UVT, and UV dose for unit.

Parameters

  • flow_in (float) – Volumetric flow into unit [MGD]

  • uvt_in (float) – UV transmission (UVT) into unit

  • uv_dose (float) – UV dose used by the unit [mg/L]

Returns

a, b

watertap3.wt_units.wt_unit module¶

class watertap3.wt_units.wt_unit.WT3UnitProcess(*args, **kwds)¶

Bases: idaes.core.process_block.ProcessBlock

Args:

rule (function): A rule function or None. Default rule calls build(). concrete (bool): If True, make this a toplevel model. Default - False. ctype (str): Pyomo ctype of the block. Default - “Block” default (dict): Default ProcessBlockData config

Keys
dynamic

Indicates whether this model will be dynamic or not, default = False. Equilibrium Reactors do not support dynamic behavior.

has_holdup

Indicates whether holdup terms should be

constructed or not.

default - False. Equilibrium reactors do not have defined volume, thus this must be False.

property_package

Property parameter object used to define property calculations,

default - useDefault. Valid values: { useDefault - use default package from parent model or flowsheet, PhysicalParameterObject - a PhysicalParameterBlock object.}

property_package_args

A ConfigBlock with arguments to be passed to a property block(s) and used when constructing these, default - None. Valid values: { see property package for documentation.}

initialize (dict): ProcessBlockData config for individual elements. Keys

are BlockData indexes and values are dictionaries described under the “default” argument above.

idx_map (function): Function to take the index of a BlockData element and

return the index in the initialize dict from which to read arguments. This can be provided to overide the default behavior of matching the BlockData index exactly to the index in initialize.

Returns:

(WT3UnitProcess) New instance
